Introduction

Overview - The purpose of this document is to provide clear strategies and procedures for the management of private patient(s) services within MSE hospitals. The relevant Business and Clinical teams endeavour to provide the highest levels of efficient, safe care by working collaboratively with our referring consultants, patients and internal teams to best support the patient journey

This policy has been developed to give clear guidance to Trust staff in relation to the Private Patient process and to ensure that all Private Patients are properly recorded and that the Trust collects the income associated with their treatment.

All Trust staff are expected to treat all paying patients and NHS patients and their relatives or representatives with dignity and respect at all times and in accordance with cultural and religious beliefs. Trust staff must extend the same courtesies to all patients regardless of status.
The Trust should make clear that no patients should lose their entitlement to NHS care they would have otherwise received, simply because they opt to purchase additional care for their condition;
As overriding rules, it is essential that:
The NHS should never subsidise private care with public money, which would breach core NHS principles;

Patients should never be charged for their NHS care, or be allowed to pay towards an NHS service (except where specific legislation is in place to allow this) as this would contravene the founding principles and legislation of the NHS.

To avoid these risks, there should be as clear a separation as possible between private and NHS care. The Trust is clear that that the provision of private patient services is a complementary service allowing the patient to have choice around the delivery of services.

Following the Merger of the three legacy Organisations (Southend University Hospitals NHS Trust, Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust and Mid Essex Hospitals NHS Trust) into the newly formed Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) there remain two varying Private Patients Operational models in place, and it is intended that these operational models will remain as is for now, with a view to reviewing and standardising post pandemic.
This policy therefore sets out the overarching principals of the Trust in respect of
private patients whilst respecting the operational delivery differences.
Current operational models can be summarised as follows:
1.8.1 Basildon Hospital The private patient services at the Basildon Hospital site offers a fully
comprehensive service model in the main contained within a dedicated Private
Patient Unit (Brook Suite).
1.8.2 Brook Suite beds do not form part of the Trust NHS capacity. These beds are ring fenced and not included within NHS bed stock.
1.8.3 The Management of this unit is via an MSE appointed Unit Manager and services are supported by the direct employment of MSE Nursing, Housekeeping and Admin staff.

1.8.4 The Trust do not employ consultants to undertake private practice, they are self- employed individuals who are subject to a Trust governance process which grants them practice privileges if appropriate guidelines are met. Medical Staffing provision is not provided directly by the Trust but subject to separate contractual arrangements.

1.8.5 The Service offered at Basildon is in the main an adult only one, providing care to patients who are 16 years and above. Children under the age of 16 would require individual review with the Ward manager, Clinical Lead and referring clinician due to the alternative care requirements for paediatric care.
1.8.2 Southend and Broomfield Hospitals The provision of Private patient services at these sites is delivered within the NHS bed base, there is no dedicated Private Patients Unit.
1.8.3 Private patient activity is fitted around NHS patients, typically at the beginning or
the end of a NHS list. The overriding principal being that no NHS patient should
ever be subject to cancellation or rescheduling to accommodate a private patient.
Medical Staffing provision is not provided directly by the Trust but subject to
separate contractual arrangements.
1.8.4 In most cases the doctor will be paid directly by the insurer or the patient. All doctors must have practice privileges and be approved by the Trusts Medical Advisory Committee Chair.

1.8.5 Local operational procedures are detailed in this policy under Appendix 4 for Basildon Hospital site and Appendix 5 for Southend and Broomfield Hospital sites and all staff should ensure these procedures are adhered to.
Scope
This policy and its precepts apply to those patients, referred to as Private Patients,
who have chosen to pay for services provided by the Trust (self-funding) or have
private healthcare insurance that will meet the costs of treatment provision (Insurance funded)
This policy specifically excludes overseas patients also known as overseas visitors, which are dealt with separately and to whom different tariffs and surcharges apply

The policy builds on the Section 65 of the National Health Service Act 1977 and admission of Paying Patients, and more recent NHS guidance: https://www.nhs.uk/common-health-questions/nhs-services-and-treatments/if-i- pay-for-private-treatment-how-will-my-nhs-care-be-affected/
Policy statement
Private patient services are an integral part of the clinical service portfolio offered by MSE which generate significant surpluses that are reinvested into NHS care at MSE

The Trust is obliged to ensure that the boundaries between NHS work and private practice are clear, transparent and understood so that the Trust can maximise private patient income by actively promoting service delivery, championing best practice and celebrating clinical excellence, subject to no adverse impact on
mainstream NHS activities.

data.text: Definitions of types of patient activity

table_items.text: Any patients who exercise the right to seek private healthcare at any stage of their treatment and who remain under the care of a private consultant for the duration of that treatment
Private patients who fund their treatment through insurance of their choice. A detailed invoice will be sent to the Insurance after the procedure has taken place.
Private patients who personally fund their treatment and who are liable for any charges that may result from that treatment. Advance payment will be expected from this category of patients.

An NHS patient who will, within a NHS Pathway, self or crowd- fund a procedure which is not otherwise commissioned by the Clinical Commissioning Group. They remain NHS patients before and after the treatment
The Trust will look to assist where capacity allows and without impacting scheduled private admissions, to accommodate NHS patients. These patients will only be accepted if they meet the
relevant admissions criteria. The transfer of these patients must be assessed and authorised by the Local PPU Management Team. A nightly bed fee will be cross charged to the speciality.

As a Trust PPU facilities do not accept patients directly from A and E and cannot be used as an escalation area. They will support the wider Trust by repatriating core speciality (Cardiology/Cardiovascular) NHS patients to free up general capacity, in close collaboration with Trust Operational Leads and the Private Patient Management team. However the use of PPU beds for general NHS patient must not impact the scheduled private patient activity. In the event of a National Major Incident (including a Pandemic), PPU units will support NHS flow and capacity if the Trust cannot accommodate a serge influx.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust
Trust Management Executive Group is the local approval group.
Chief Executive
The Chief Executive as Accounting Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust
Chief Finance Officer / Chief Nursing Officer / Chief Medical Officer
The Chief Finance Officer, Chief Nursing Officer and Chief Medical Officer will be corporately responsible for the implementation of this document.
This includes:
The identification of when the document is reviewed and updated and the time frame for the process to be undertaken.
The identification of the responsible Governance sub-committee to have  monitoring reports sent to.
Ensuring that the Trust provides and supports the training required for staff to undertake the task and that there is an appropriate competency framework to support this.
Medical Staff
To be aware of and comply with the procedure for the management of incidents and complaints are followed in the event of deviation from the care outline in the procedures within this document.

Ensuring that all private patient episodes are notified at the outset to the relevant Unit /Private Patient Manager to ensure all costs are calculated and covered either by the Patients themselves or their elected Insurance Company

Ensuring, via the relevant unit/Private Patient Manager, there are adequate resources within the Hospital to undertake the private procedure. The relevant manager will then liaise with the clinical departments to confirm that there is bed, surgical or outpatient capacity/ support available whenever necessary before the private case can go ahead
Clinical Directors/Directors of Operations
Clinical Directors and Directors of Operations are responsible for the implementation of this policy at Divisional level. This includes:
Identifying training needs and assessing against what the service is delivering
Ensuring that the Monitoring and Audit of this document are completed and reported as required.
Associate Directors of Nursing/ General Managers /Clinical Leads/ Unit Managers / Heads of Nursing / Matron/ Ward Managers
The above staff are responsible for the implementation of this document at service level. This includes:
Identifying and support training needs.
Benchmarking the service delivery.
Managing all aspects of governance (corporate, finance and clinical) at a service
Ensuring the day-to-day compliance with all aspects this document
Ensuring the document is communicated to the appropriate staff and embedded within the service
Ensuring the site specific procedures for notification of Private patient activity are adhered to
Ensuring the site specific procedures for recording of resources utilised in the provision of private patient activity are adhered to
Registered Nursing Staff

To be aware of and comply with the procedure for the management of private patient(s). To ensure that the Trust governance policies including management of incidents and complaints are followed in the event of deviation from the care outline in the procedures within this document.
To ensure any deviation from this policy is escalated to the most appropriate manager and if reasonable to do so, incident reported under failure to follow guidance.
Health Care Assistants

To be aware of and comply with the procedure for the management of private patient(s).To ensure that the Trust governance policies including management of incidents and complaints are followed in the event of deviation from the care outline in the procedures within this document.
Private Patient Manager
To provide leadership and guidance to the local hospital teams and effectively manage consultant relationships to ensure the private patient experience is consistently delivered.

To control, monitor and be responsible for the full Private Patient financial performance at all sites. Including the responsibility for obtaining payment or confirmation of agreement to pay from insurers prior to the commencement of a pathway
To Act as the primary contact for key stakeholders and private patients.
To deliver exceptional service, providing timely updates to patients and ensuring they are fully supported and informed throughout their journey.
All Trust Staff
All staff via their Local Induction, should be referred to and familiarise themselves with this policy and their roles and responsibilities within it.
Private patients pathways

With increasing emphasis on patient choice it is recognised that patients may move between NHS and private healthcare at different stages in their care, however, there must be as clear a separation as possible between their private treatment and NHS treatment. Patients should receive their private care at a different time and place from their NHS care and they cannot choose to mix NHS and private care for different parts of the same treatment/pathway.

A private inpatient will be regarded as a private patient for the duration of their in-patient episode, their private status also extending to any outpatient activity that might be needed as part of the same course of treatment. Similarly, a private patient cannot revert to being a NHS patient midway through an outpatient course of treatment. Should a consultant refer his private patients for NHS diagnostic or paramedical treatment, tests or procedures, these will be treated as a continuation of the private episode, and therefore chargeable care, unless the patient wishes to revert to NHS commissioned care – in this instance the Patient will be referred back to their GP as per 5.3

Patients who wish to transfer from private outpatient to NHS care must go via their GP for Assessment and onward referral for NHS commissioned care. They will, at that point, be entitled to be provided with any drugs or other treatment which would have been provided to any other NHS patient and be subject to the same waiting times. If prior to reverting to NHS care, a patient was on a drugs regimen that would not be routinely funded under the NHS, they will remain chargeable for those medications, on a private basis and separately from their NHS episode.

When treating a private patient all activity and consumables used throughout the patients stay should be recorded to ensure the entire pathway is costed and reclaimed correctly. Any changes to a patient's treatment plan or LOS should be clearly recorded on the Trust Patient Administration system and communicated to the Private Patients /Brooke Suite Unit Manager.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Trust Management Executive Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the relevant audience of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

Raising awareness of the policy's content and its implications for specific groups of staff will be the responsibility of the Clinical Directors, Clinical Leads and Associate Directors of Operations (ADOs).
Staff training

All staff must receive a Local Induction, and this policy and the role of the PPU and PPU Management and the services they provide must be highlighted to those whose roles and responsibilities include managing the procedures described in this policy
Training will be provided as per the training needs analysis and included in the consultant induction programme.
All MSE Sites follow all Trust policies and procedures with regard to
Safeguarding Children and Vulnerable Adults
Equality and Diversity
Information Governance
Standing Financial Instructions
Incident and Complaint Management (The only exception is with regards to complaints adjudication whereby, Brooke Suite contract the services of ISCAS)
Health and Safety and Infection, prevention and control
All staff are expected to maintain their mandatory and core training compliances. This is the responsibility of all staff and should be managed by line managers.
Policy review and audit
The policy will be reviewed annually or earlier if legislation, guidance or Trust financial requirements change.
The Trust will audit the implementation of the policy by monitoring progress and reviewing compliance against:
The number of formal / informal complaints related to Paying Patient services within the Trust
The number of Paying Patients accessing services within the Trust
The amount of income generated for Paying Patients episodes
The number of Insurance Companies accepting the Trust as the place of treatment for their client
Results from audits will be reported to the most relevant person in the Trust, depending on the subject of the audit. .
Equality impact assessment
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

data.text: Appendix 4: Basildon hospital operational policy
Brook Suite Operations Meeting – Responsible for having oversight and providing steer for all private activity. This includes performance monitoring and financial governance.

CTC Governance Board – Responsible for ensuring that the document is adequately formatted and approved via the correct process. Also responsible for ensuring this document is adhered to and implemented.
CTC Divisional Board – Responsible for monitoring and management of the CTC Governance Board.
CTC Performance Board – Responsible as a point of escalation for all divisional issues as well as having oversight of the divisional performance and monitoring of this

As referenced in 1.8 Basildon Hospital Site offers a fully comprehensive service model in the main contained within a dedicated Private Patient Unit (Brook Suite). Brook Suite beds do not form part of the Trust NHS capacity. These beds are ring fenced and not included within NHS bed stock.

However, at times of peak demand, the pressures of operational delivery can conflict with the priorities of service delivery. The procedures set out in this document provide the steps required to ensure private patient activity remains unaffected by other pressures while also ensuring Brook Suite supports the wider Trust to its fullest extent.

The Unit is managed by a triumvirate structure including the Clinical Lead, Unit Manager and Ward Manager. Please see the below organogram for clarity on the lines of escalation and managerial responsibilities

To support the operational delivery of the unit there is a level of employment of MSE Nursing, Housekeeping and Admin staff. Medical Staffing provision is not provided directly by the Trust but is subject to separate contractual arrangements.

Brook Suite comprises 8 inpatient beds, ring-fenced for private patients to ensure the balance between NHS and private services as outlined above. The unit accepts levels 0 and 1 (DoH, 2000). The unit is operationally managed by the Local Private Patients Management Team which consists of the Unit Manager, Ward Manager, Business Team and Nursing Team. It is in the interests of the Trust to ensure Brook Suite beds are utilised to their maximum potential. Managing the access and use of NHS patients in this way:
Protects the reputation of the Trust as NHS patients may not be cancelled through lack of beds.
Provides NHS income to the Trust for patients who may otherwise have been cancelled due to lack of NHS beds.
Increases good will and foster a culture of mutual support and cooperation between Divisions.
Demonstrably ensures the most efficient use of the PPU beds. NB: a cross- charge is made to Brook Suite, based on overheads and the cost of staffing the ward.
The Private Patients Management Team will operate bed allocation as per the chart in figure 1 below.
The Brook Suite works under the direction of the MSE policies and procedures which are available by the intranet and embedded throughout the teams locally.

The beds on the unit are ring-fenced and not counted within the NHS bed stock on the Basildon site, a principle previously formally endorsed by the Joint Working Board and BTUH Site Leadership Team, and unchanged following the formal merger of the Trusts to create the Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust. This means that their use must be strictly regulated to support the business model.

To maximise efficiency, and to support internal pressures, beds can be utilised to accommodate NHS patients. The most common example of this the repatriation of patients to free up a ‘hot bed' within the CTC or accommodation of elective admissions to avoid cancellation. These will be cross charged to the NHS budgets at an agreed nightly rate. There is a robust criteria of acceptance to allow protection of private patient flow and patient suitability will be assessed on a case by case basis.
The criteria are as follows:
Patients for transfer/repatriation to the CTC:
Will need to be ready and safe for discharge within 24 hours of transfer to allow bed usage to be worked into current flow.
BTUH Surgical patient;
Must have a clear plan for discharge the following day, no later.
Elective admissions:

Need to have a confirmed treatment/procedure slot for no later than the following day and have a clear postoperative or post-procedural NHS pathway planned including repatriation to an NHS bed at the earliest possible, safe time to do so.
Patients who are de-escalated from ITU:

To free up capacity to allow surgical patients to go to theatre and be recovered in ITU need to be assessed as clinically stable to step down. There needs to be future NHS bed capacity identified to facilitate transfer back to their NHS pathway at the earliest possible, safe time to do so.

When the Trust are operating at Opel 3 or above escalation status there must always be one bed left empty to allow a private ‘take' bed to accommodate an emergency private admission. If the Trust are operating Opel 4, internal or external critical incident escalation status, this bed will be used to appropriately support internal patient flow. The management of the bed base will be managed by the local PPU management team in close collaboration with the incident management team

Conversely, the PPU Management Team will work closely with the Director(s) of Operations to ‘purchase' additional capacity from the NHS at an agreed rate, if the private admissions exceed private bed capacity.

It is important that there is a clear differentiation in the service provided to private patients receiving care on Brook Suite. The provision of this service is a stipulation of contractual arrangements with the insurers and an expectation of those paying for their treatment.
Patients on Brook Suite will:
Be greeted by a welcoming member of the Brook team
Be shown to the area in which they are required to be for their treatment/procedure/diagnostic on the day
Have access to the dedicated Brook Suite business team to manage their pathway from point of referral to point of discharge
Be nursed in single, ensuite accommodation (with the exception of care received on ITU or if clinical need dictates)
Have open visiting times (when clinically appropriate)
Be provided with high quality linen and towels
Have toiletries as required
Have televisions with access to internet applications
Have access to free Wi-Fi
Be offered free newspapers of their choice
Have access to beverages on demand
Be offered a bespoke menu, cooked to order
Be entitled to free car parking (one car per patient)

Hospitality arrangements and service provision will be under constant review through patient experience feedback. Suggestions will be taken into account, with modifications and improvements being made in response, to ensure the highest quality of service delivery.

Brook Suite is a private patient unit housed within the Essex Cardiothoracic Centre which is part of Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust. The Essex Cardiothoracic Centre is a specialist tertiary centre which was built in 2007 with the aim of providing specialist cardiology and cardiovascular care for patient throughout the region. As this is a tertiary centre, patients are received from all over the country. The Brook Suite PPU will accept any patient referred by one of the admitting consultants* – please note all Trust and Brook Suite policies and procedures should be adhered in the referral/acceptance process and acceptance rates may vary dependant on capacity and NHS Standards Contract variations.
Brook Suite can support a wide range of inpatient and day-case procedures as well as diagnostic and outpatient services.
*If a consultant wishes to use the MSE, Brooke Suite private patient services but does not have
admitting rights, this can be arranged via the Executive Assistant. This guidance also only applies to private patients.

data.text: To staff the unit of any given day there must be a minimum of:
Unit manager or Ward manager
1 Business support assistant
1 Business accounts assistant
2 Qualified nurses
2 HCA
1 Hospitality Assistants
Brook suite operates the inpatient/day-case ward  hours a day, 7 days a week with the exception of bank holidays or periods of lesser demand.
The Business team office hours are Monday – Friday 08:00 – 18:00 The reception hours are Monday – Friday 08:00 – 15:00

The Brook Suite Business Team hold weekly or bi-weekly team meetings which feed into the monthly Operations meeting. If there are areas for escalation this can be taken to the CTC Governance board or CTC performance board.

It is the role of the Brook Suite Business Management Team to broadly lead and efficiently manage the end-to-end private patient service while providing guidance, support and leadership to the staff working under the umbrella of Brook Suite.
Within the Business Team; who are led by the Unit Manager, the team create a support network for each other and cross-cover each other for leave and other absences.
The nursing and HCA staff; who are led by the Ward Manager, have a mentorship process whereby they each have a support mentor.
Clinical processes

The booking process must be strictly adhered to, in order to provide a mechanism to allow patients to be safely booked into the service. Consultants are expected to fully complete a booking form which details the following information as a minimum:
Patient demographics including date of birth (and hospital number, if the patient has had a previous admission)
Details of their insurance company, policy number any pre-authorisation information
Confirmation that if they are not insured that they wish to self-fund treatment and that treatment costs have been discussed and agreed
Detailed information regarding the procedure including the correct coding
Date and time of procedure and planned admission time
Specific pre-operative or pre-procedural instructions including omission of medication or fasting
Pre-assessment arrangements if appropriate
Predicted length of stay
The Business Team are unable to book any procedures or admissions if this form has not been completed in full and submitted and have the right to refuse bookings in the absence of a booking form.

It is the responsibility of the admitting consultant to complete this process. The decision to admit a patient privately and the price that is agreed to provide this treatment rests solely with the Private Patients Management Team. Patients are informed through the Private Healthcare Self Pay Terms and Conditions (Appendix 7 that only communications from the Private Patients Unit at Basildon can be construed as terms and conditions which bind The Trust and that any discussions or correspondence undertaken directly with consultants or other parties are not incorporated into the contract with Trust

On their first admission, patients will be asked to complete a registration form which provides the Business Team with the core information required to register the patient on the Trust's EPR system. This will create an electronic record which will allow the patient to have their procedure booked onto an electronic booking system (CVIS/ORMIS).

The registration form also includes an integral undertaking to pay form. The purpose and legal implications of this form must be fully explained prior to signing by a member of the Business Team. The patient will be unable to proceed unless this is signed and dated. This form provides a formal record of acknowledgement that they are liable for all costs, should their private medical insurer not meet these

on completion of treatment. Pre-authorisation is not a guarantee of payment and will not cover any excesses or shortfalls underwritten within the policy. Patient liability must be highlighted, and the patient made aware immediately. The Trust will hold the patient liable for any shortfalls and invoice for the amount stipulated by their insurer.

Patients will be scheduled for admission to correspond with the consultant's private lists. This may be on the day of procedure/surgery or the night before. Detailed information regarding fasting and drug regimens will be given to the patient by the consultant and reiterated within written pre-admission correspondence. This information should correspond with the information submitted by the Consultant on the booking form to ensure consistency and to provide a formal audit trial.

Bed allocation is dependency driven and is finalised by the Ward Manager/Nurse in Charge to ensure safe staffing ratios and efficient bed utilisation. Acuity scoring is undertaken daily and uploaded via the Hub to map safer staffing requirements. Any discrepancy must be flagged and addressed in a timely fashion to ensure safe staffing ratios. If this is not achievable through the utilisation of substantive and Bank staff, this should be discussed with the Consultant and with the CTC Duty Sister to explore all options before delaying a case.

Rooms on Brook Suite are used to full capacity and it is essential that rooms are vacated to allow for ongoing usage. This needs to be communicated to patients and their relatives in pre-admission documentation and verbally during the admission process. When a patient is taken to theatre for surgery, their belongings will be stored safely until they return to the unit.

Relatives will be asked to wait in the Relatives Room on the unit during the patient's surgical procedure until they have been admitted to ITU for recovery. When patients are admitted to ITU, the Nurse in Charge on Brook Suite will liaise with the Nurse in Charge on ITU to provide information on timescales to enable visiting. This may vary based on the patient's clinical stability post-operatively. The Nurse in Charge on Brook Suite will communicate all updates and timelines to relatives to endeavour to minimise their anxiety.

Prior to admission patients will be reviewed by their consultant on an outpatient basis. This may take place on site or at any private provider. An outpatient summary should be provided to the Business Team, which will be filed in the patient's records. Baseline screening including observations, height, weight, ECG, and blood profile should be undertaken and recorded in the patient's records.

Any clinical concerns arising from an outpatient review must be highlighted by the consultant and discussed with the Ward Manager (or a senior member of the clinical team in their absence), who assumes clinical responsibility for the Unit. These concerns must be clearly documented on the admission request to allow

effective dependency screening. This includes any specific food allergies or dietary requirements, so that dietary provision can be planned effectively. This may require a pre-treatment assessment with the Trust's Dietetic Team.

If a patient requires a pre-admission appointment, this should be undertaken by a senior, trained member of the clinical team and arranged via the Brook Suite Business Team, in close collaboration with the Ward Manager. This should be arranged to provide sufficient time to obtain an MRSA status and to cross match peri-operative blood if required.

The pre-admission process provides an opportunity to fully prepare and screen patients for their treatment pathway and ensure compliance with the Trust's Policy for the Prevention of Surgical Site Infections and Infection Control Policy for Management and Control of MRSA.

The staff member undertaking the pre-assessment process is responsible for tracking all blood results and escalating any abnormal results to the consultant. They are also responsible for outlining outstanding or day of surgery blood work that is required as part of pre-operative preparation to ensure that these are fulfilled by the admitting team. Allergies must be clearly documented within the patient's records.

Patients should receive written information covering all aspects of their treatment and contact numbers to allow them to speak to the clinical team to clarify any outstanding questions prior to admission.

They should also be fully orientated to the clinical environment and the location of all treatment areas included within their care pathway during the pre-assessment process. Admission timings and practicalities such as parking, what they need to bring and visiting arrangements, should also be discussed.

Patients for outpatients and diagnostic services should be referred in via the Brook Suite business team as with all other referrals. The business team will arrange a slot for the patient in line with the consultants' requirements. The business team will communicate with the patient throughout the pathway to communicate all relevant information and deal with any queries or concerns the patient may have. At all times, the referring consultant is responsible for the patient and must ensure that any diagnostics requested are clinically appropriate and safe for that patient.

cc.  Admitting rights/Consultant practising privileges

Before a doctor can work within the Private Patient Unit at Basildon admitting rights or practicing privileges need to be obtained. The unit runs a MAC that comprises of consultants from all subspecialties, one of whom is the Chairperson.

The MAC will grant practicing privileges to consultants who meet the standards set by the MAC. Practicing privileges are not awarded by right; and The PPU Private Patients may refuse, after deliberation and investigation, to deny practicing privileges to consultants who meet the criteria.

Consultants must adhere to the appropriate clinical governance and service provision requirements set out and agreed by the MAC. Failure to meet with these requirements will be formally investigated and monitored and may lead to a withdrawal of practicing privileges.
The Private Healthcare Medical Society Handbook – The Rights and Responsibilities Document (2018) outlines these processes and criteria in full and should be referred to for guidance.
Eligibility criteria:
In addition to the Trust's employment checks, all doctors requesting practicing privileges must provide the following:
DBS clearance and subscription to the update service
GMC registration
Evidence of registration with PMI
Evidence of annual appraisals with the Trust and fulfilment of CPD requirements

Proof of membership of a Medical Defence Organisation - This indemnity must cover clinical negligence claims, complaints procedures, Good Samaritan acts, advice on legal and ethical dilemmas arising from professional practice, GMC enquiries, disciplinary procedures, inquests and fatal accident enquiries, and police investigations arising from professional practice
Provision of details pertaining to a Limited Company for individual practitioners
Provision of details pertaining to a Limited Liability Partnership for practitioners belonging to a Chambers or Consortium
Evidence of registration with the ICO and compliance with the GDPR
Evidence of compliance with all CMA stipulations

This evidence will be collated by the Private Patient units Executive Assistant, who works in close collaboration with Human Resources to ensure that all evidence is submitted and accurate. Evidence will be ratified by the Clinical Lead, with any concerns being raised through the MAC

gg. Treatment of Private Patients Transferring to the NHS
Patients who choose to be treated privately are entitled to NHS services on exactly the same basis of clinical need as any other patient.
Where a patient wishes to change from private to NHS status, Consultants should ensure that the following principles apply:

Private patients are normally expected to remain private throughout their whole treatment episode and should not transfer to the NHS unless there is a significant and unforeseen change in clinical circumstances. The patient is nonetheless legally entitled to change status at a subsequent visit and seek treatment under the NHS, subject to the terms of any undertaking made to pay charges.
A patient cannot be both a private and an NHS patient for the treatment of any one condition during a single visit/in the same setting.

Any patient seen privately is entitled to subsequently change his/her status and seek treatment as an NHS patient. This must not occur during the same episode of care. Patients should be re-referred and seen within a separate episode of care.

Any patient changing their status after having been provided with private services should not be treated on a different basis to other NHS patients as a result of having previously held private status.

Patients referred for an NHS service following a private consultation or private  treatment should join any NHS waiting list at the same point as if the consultation or treatment were an NHS service (including the likely date of that consultation). Their priority on the waiting list should be determined by the same clinical criteria applied to other NHS patients.

Consultants may not add patients seen privately directly onto their Trust NHS waiting list, or to undergo investigations as an NHS patient. The Consultant must write to the patient's GP requesting a NHS referral. The date of this referral is the start of the patient's subsequent 18-week pathway; it also serves to confirm that the GP's Clinical Commissioning Group will accept responsibility for funding the patient's ongoing NHS treatment. There is no requirement for the patient to revisit their GP, nor have an additional NHS
outpatient consultation at the Trust.

Alternatively, the Consultant may refer the patient back to their GP to refer as they see fit. This may be appropriate if patients experience new symptoms or if they deviate from their original treatment pathway.

If a patient has had investigations/diagnostics at Basildon Hospital privately or at another private facility but wishes to transfer to a Trust waiting list for an operation or procedure, then they may do so, subject to eligibility for NHS care and to the provisions of the stipulations above.

If the patient requires outpatient investigations at the Trust and/or follow up appointments as an NHS patient, then the investigations may be organised as an NHS patient. The patient's first outpatient appointment must be as a new, rather than a follow-up, consultation.

Once a patient has transferred from private care to NHS care, they must remain an NHS patient for the duration of that episode of treatment. It is not acceptable for patients initially to be seen privately, to transfer to NHS care for treatment or investigations.

Should a patient be admitted to an NHS hospital as a private in-patient but subsequently decide to change to NHS status before having received treatment, there should be an assessment to determine the patient's priority for NHS care. In some circumstances, unless it is clinically inappropriate to do so, it may be necessary to discharge such a patient and then readmit them only at such time as they would normally have been admitted should they have retained NHS status throughout.
hh. Rationale and Procedure for Closing Brook Suite

When there are no private patients booked to utilise Brook Suite, the Brook Suite Management Team will work with the CTC Management Team to ascertain current capacity demands for the CTC. If Brook Suite beds are required to supplement CTC capacity, then the unit will repatriate mutually agreed patients (as per ‘Specific Structure and Escalation Process for Utilisation of Brook Suite Beds').

If capacity demand has been fully assessed and Brook Suite beds are not required, the Brook Suite Management Team will discuss potential closure with the Director of Operations and on agreement will close the unit and notify all stakeholders of this closure.

The Nurse in Charge will inform the Control Centre for Teletracking (Ext 2000) when Brook Suite is closed and instruct them to block the beds on the system until further notification when the ward reopens. The Nurse in Charge needs to explain that the ward will be closed and there will not be any staff on the ward. This will prevent inappropriate escalation.
Redeployment of staff will be agreed and managed systematically in collaboration with the CTC Duty Sister

If Brook Suite is closed, the Nurse in Charge will ensure that a standardised answerphone message is activated which signposts patients to access help. The Nurse in Charge or the Brook Suite Management Team will provide the CTC Duty Sister with their contact number and act as a point of contact should the unit need to be opened at short notice and will have rostered staff contact numbers to allow them to summon the team in. Shifts will be paid in full if staff are required to come in on short notice.
ii.  Utilisation of Staff in the event of closure

The utilisation of staffing/bed management model is aligned to the wider business model. This principal needs to be endorsed by the teams within the CTC and the wider Trust, as their support in delivering this model and income generation will enable the financial rewards to be practically realised. It will also have a positive impact on their establishment and operating targets going forward.
When the unit is closed the following process will be followed:
The nurse in charge contacts the duty sister to assess the establishment needs within the wider CTC

A review of the current/planned workforce is made to see if staff can be utilised within a department in the CTC. The nurse in charge will speak to the Ward Manager and/or the Brook Suite Management Team to agree the most clinically appropriate use of the staff based on predicated admissions and workflow

If staffing is adequate within the CTC, the nurse in charge will need to work with the CTC duty sister to ascertain the status of the wider Trust. If the wider Trust is on is on Opel 3/4 status internal/critical incident, it is highly likely that staff will be required to work in other areas outside the CTC. Staff will be fully supported by the substantive teams.
In the case of the declaration of a major incident, the Brook Suite Management Team will fully support the Trust to release capacity and staff should it be required
Staff who are deployed to other wards will be charged to the ward they are allocated to for the time they provide

Equally, if staff are provided to Brook Suite by other wards, the ward they originated from will be reimbursed by Brook Suite for their time using the same pricing matrix, so that this is fair and transparent

The unit must always maintain minimum staffing numbers and ratios. Safer staffing levels are set at 2 x trained and 2 x HCA (day shift) and 2 x trained and 1 x HCA (night shift) and were set following CQC
recommendations. When the unit is functioning on minimum staffing levels, staff must not be moved to another areas

If there are no outstanding staffing requirements, Brook Suite staff are to be sent home, or their shifts will be cancelled. These shifts will then be reallocated to provide cover for outstanding shifts within the current rota to minimise the need for bank and agency usage. If there are no outstanding shifts, the staff member will be offered annual leave.

order is placed. Alternatively, the patient has the option to purchase any appliance independently (if required the Trust will provide a list of D.H.S. Approved suppliers albeit the Trust does not preferentially endorse any supplier). Single use appliances will be charged for in full. Also, all walking aids must be charged for.
k.  Patient transfers from/to a private hospital

i.  Consultants should inform the PPO if intending to transfer to the Hospital a patient who wishes to continue to be treated as a private patient. In this case the PPO will check with the patients' medical insurance company to ensure that cover is provided. The patient must then be admitted direct to the ward and should not be directed to the A and E Department.
